Cromartie''''', 532 US 234 (2001), also known as Hunt v. Cromartie, was a [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] case. The court's ruling on April 18, 2001 stated that redistricting for political reasons did not violate Federal [[Civil Rights]] Law banning race-based [[gerrymandering]]. (Case No. 99-1864). The Supreme Court held in the case that as [[Southern United States|Southern]] [[African American|blacks]] tend to vote for the [[United States Democratic Party|Democratic Party]], [[North Carolina's 12th congressional district]] was drawn based upon voting behavior, instead of upon racial characteristics. The allegedly odd-shaped district was allowed to stand. Critics of this ruling found this to be a case of judicial nitpicking and that the Court had in essence allowed the previously-banned practice of concentrating a racial group into a single district. ==See also== * [[List of United States Supreme Court cases, volume 532]] * [[List of United States Supreme Court cases]] ==Further reading== *{{cite journal |last=Kravetz |first=R.
